record.text:
QUESTION: What books are you all reading? Fiction, nonfiction, whatever‚Äîwhat are the books you're reading and liking now, or that you've recently enjoyed? (Yes, audiobooks count!)

(Asking for a ... me.)
Jo Nesbo the Harry Hole series.
Just finished The Index of Self Destructive Acts ‚Äî Christopher Beha. Highly recommend it!

I‚Äôm reading and enjoying ‚ÄúInterior Chinatown,‚Äù by Charles Yu. 
www.barnesandnoble.com/w/interior-c...
Just borrowed a bio about Elmore Leonard from the library that looks good. www.harpercollins.com/products/coo...
James Lee Burke's The Hadacol Boogie. Outstanding.
So, so good
I recently ate all volumes of The Unselected Journals of Emma M. Lion like they were popcorn.

Rereading Cosmos by Carl Sagan 

listening to Hyperion by Dan Simmons
I finally got around to 'Hyperion' in 2024 but haven't done the rest in that series yet, maybe I will this month.
I've just bought 'Paper', by Mark Kurlansky. Haven't started it yet, but I loved his previous history-of-a-much-more-interestingitem-than-you-might-have-thought books.
Thanks for the lead!

wwnorton.com/books/fault-...

I turned 18 in 1974 and was working as a summer intern at the USDA Rural Electrification Admin when Nixon resigned. Always meant to look back at the big arc, but, you know, moved to DK, back again, family issues, etc. This nails it.

The Hidden Life of Trees (escape from politics category), How To Stand Up To A Dictator (protest category), The Bird Hotel (Joyce Maynard,  fiction). 1984 (both fiction and nonfiction categories).
Just finished Three Bags Full by Leonie Swann. A murder mystery...solved by sheep. Fun. Weird.

I started the audiobook last weekend. (I have reservations about the narrator.) 

I have read the first two chapters, and so far it's excellent. Part fiction and simulation; part analysis of what we just went through. Are we ready for the Big One?

Sadly not.

‚ÄúThe silence is so loud
And everything's unspoken now‚Äù

images.alt: Cover of ‚ÄúThe Elephant in the Room: Silence and Denial in Everyday Life‚Äù by Eviatar Zerubavel

record.text:
Fiction: In Memoriam, by Alice Winn

Nonfiction: When the Sea Came Alive: An Oral History of D-Day, by Garrett Graff

Both are great but Graff's book is tremendous.  Can really highly recommend it!

I‚Äôve been going back to Terry Pratchett‚Äôs Discworld novels, and I‚Äôm reminded how sharp they really are. Small Gods on the machinery of organized belief. Night Watch on how fragile institutions can be. Jingo on the absurd ease of sliding into war. The Truth on propaganda, media, and power.

They get shelved as ‚Äúfantasy,‚Äù but they‚Äôre really some of the clearest, funniest, and most humane writing about politics and society I‚Äôve ever read. Pratchett had a way of making you laugh, then making you uneasy about why you were laughing.

I was just re-listening to Wyrd Sisters which is one of my favourites. He has far more to say, indeed, about some serious subjects, than many authors (incl fantasy ones) who aren‚Äôt tagged as humorous
I‚Äôve four more non Tiffany Aching ones to read; got stalled in Unseen Academicals.  Will get back to them this year.  Vimes is the best.
Yes, Night Watch is excellent

record.text:
Just finished reading Cold Comfort Farm out loud to my wife.

Odd, overall good.

Just finished The Last Lion: Winston Spencer Churchill: Alone, 1932‚Äì1940 by William Manchester. Fascinating look at the life of Churchill during the time no one thought the Nazis were a big deal. Not sure you need part one but Churchill‚Äôs time in the wilderness has some interesting lessons for us.
Love that book ‚Äî and Paul Reid, who finished part three after Manchester's death, is here on Bluesky: @pepper99.bsky.social
TY, Sir!

record.text: Professionally: Eric Foner‚Äôs two Reconstruction books, Jazmine Ulloa‚Äôs El Paso book. For fun: Robert Harris‚Äôs ‚ÄúFatherland‚Äù.
(Unrelatedly, @adamkeiper.com, your Bluesky Lullaby posts are one of my favorite things about this site. Thank you for doing them - please keep it up.)
that's so very kind of you, thanks
I read Fatherland in safer times. I suspect it would be a very different experience in today's world
Very well done audiobook

images.alt: The cover of Mark Shaw's "Beneath the Mask of Holiness: Thomas Merton and the forbidden love affair that set him free." The lower third of the cover has a black and white picture of Thomas Merton from the chest up wearing the white robes and black scapular with cowl of a Trappist monk. He is a white male with a balding head of hair. He has his arms crossed and is looking to his right. He is standing in a field and you can see trees and hills in the background. The top third is a light beige back of an envelope with the title of the book.

record.text: A compelling look at a very complex figure that his superiors tried to simplify for their own greed. The man is much more interesting than the monk. (And I like the monk!)

images.alt: The cover of Mark Shaw's "Beneath the Mask of Holiness: Thomas Merton and the forbidden love affair that set him free." record.text: For the second time the nonfiction ‚ÄúOn Time and Water‚Äù by @andrimagnason.bsky.social, writer from Earth‚Äôs most resplendent island. Reading a second time because 1) I‚Äôm too dense and/or small-brained to have absorbed it all on just one reading, and 2) it‚Äôs enriching, illuminating, and important.
Honestly, The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet  by Becky Chambers is the kind of book that makes you fall in love in reading again.
I remember loving it and its sequel but never got around to the one after that; I should rectify that.

record.text: The Reformatory by Tananarive Due was the best book I read in 2025. I cannot recommend this book enough.
Reading Copaganda: how police and the media manipulate our news right now. By Alec Karakatsanis. An eye-opening read.

"Valiant Ambition" by Nathaniel Philbrick, the second in a trilogy about the American Revolution. "A Tomb with a View" by Peter Ross. And a complete change of pace: "The Last Devil to Die" by Richard Osman.

external.description: ALT: a man in a suit and tie is smiling in an office .
external.title: a man in a suit and tie is smiling in an office .

record.text: Volume three ("Blue Mars") of Kim Stanley Robinson's Red Mars trilogy. Gotta be honest, it's a tough slog. KSR can be *very* wordy. The trick is to just skim over any paragraph covering more than one page.

external.title: a man in a suit and tie is smiling in an office .
external.description: ALT: a man in a suit and tie is smiling in an office .

record.text: Hahaha, yeah, that's how I remember the second and third volumes of that trilogy as well.
The Correspondent and Theo of Golden were both great!

Written on the Dark is a lovely expansion on Kay‚Äôs world. I still think Tigana is his masterpiece, but I love these magical retellings of historical events. And he‚Äôs a skeeter! Much love to @guygavrielkay.bsky.social
Finishing up (at last) In Search of Lost Time with Time Regained (or Finding Time Again as my translation calls it).
Phantoms of a Beleaguered Republic

After reading and thinking way too much about late-stage capitalism and tech billionaire escape fantasies, I went looking for something a bit more grounded in actual humanity. I found out that Michael Pollan had published this book, which had passed completely under my radar.

external.description: What the New Science of Psychedelics Teaches Us About Consciousness, Dying, Addiction, Depression, and Transcendence When Michael Pollan set out to research how LSD and psilocybin (the active ingredie...
external.title: How to Change Your Mind - Michael Pollan

record.text: michaelpollan.com/books/how-to...

external.title: How to Change Your Mind - Michael Pollan
external.description: What the New Science of Psychedelics Teaches Us About Consciousness, Dying, Addiction, Depression, and Transcendence When Michael Pollan set out to research how LSD and psilocybin (the active ingredie...

record.text: It's a fascinating read. Don't misinterpret the title; it's curious science guy Pollan meditating on consciousness, ego, transience, and spirituality. Not something I necessarily would have expected from him, but he is incredibly gifted at it
I just finished "Katabasis", by Rebecca Kuang. A terrific dark fantasy/romance novel with biting commentary on academia.
The Demon of Unrest by Erik Larson

Currently reading the 3rd (chronologically) Company Wars book by C. J. Cherryh. It's some such a great job of portraying a war with out any fighting and not glorifying it. It's mostly about the bureaucracy of dealing with refugees and how they are basically immediately treated as criminals...

Despite their only crime being fleeing from a war. I also really like the depiction of the struggles of making a semi-earth like world livable and balancing (or not balancing) the forced/volunteer work force to get it done. Really love her works and recommend all of them.

In the winter I read cozy mysteries and quiet, contemplative prose and poetry. Recently I hve enjoyed What a Plant Knows by Daniel Chamovitz, Quantum Gravity by Carlo Rovelli, My Murder by Katie Williams, and Good Bones by Maggie Smith.

Recently read Proof of My Innocence ( J. Coe), Amsterdam (I. Mcewan, and Man In the Queue (J. Tey).
Re-reading Anna Karenina. Started watching a 30 yo BBC take and decided to read it again before watching all of it.
It's been a few years for me, time for a reread!
It‚Äôs the kind of book that changes with age. There are many books I re-read about every ten, 12 years.
‚ÄúJesse James: Last Rebel of the Civil War‚Äù by TJ Stiles. It is great!!

Finishing the Thursday Murder Club series.  Great for an escape from the real
World.
